title: Tidbits about 'Goosebumps' author R.L. Stine | Entertainment News
text:
R.L. Stine is a master of mystery, but his life is -- while not an open book -- the subject of a book.
His story is told in "It Came From Ohio!" subtitled "My Life as a Writer," by Mr. Stine, as told to Joe Arthur and Susan Lurie. Scholastic Books published it in 1997 and updated it in 2015; it's designed to appeal to fourth- to sixth-graders.
Some tidbits gleaned from the book, as "Goosebumps" opens:
-- R.L. stands for Robert Lawrence and friends call him Bob.
-- He was born in Bexley, a suburb of Columbus, Ohio, on Oct. 8, 1943, so he just turned 72.
-- To the horror of typing teachers everywhere (if such a profession still exists), he is a one-finger typist but a speedy one.
-- That didn't stop him from writing roughly 330 books, including "scary ones, joke books, funny books, adventure books, choose-your-own-ending books, and so on," he says in answering the 20 most asked questions in the back of "It Came From Ohio!"
-- He was a fearful boy and clearly recalls being panic-stricken and embarrassed at a day camp when he could not jump into a swimming pool as part of a Red Cross badge test. That moment serves him when he writes about a child who is terrified.
-- As a lover of comic books, he once wanted to draw comics but gravitated toward producing his own magazines and, eventually, writing.
-- When asked by his parents what he wanted for a bar mitzvah gift, he said a new typewriter. "They bought me an office-type machine. We're talking a heavy-duty typewriter here. It was perfect. I used that typewriter for years."
-- George A. Romero's "Night of the Living Dead" was one of his favorite horror movies as a boy. So was "It Came From Beneath the Sea."
-- He wrote the first "Goosebumps" book, "Welcome to Dead House," in a little over 10 days. It typically takes six weeks to write a "Fear Street" novel, three for "Goosebumps" plus a week outlining each book.
-- Actor Jack Black, who plays a movie version of Stine, told him: "I'm going to play you as you -- only a lot more sinister." That sounded perfect to the man once described by an Ohio newspaper this way: "In person, R.L. Stine is about as scary as an optometrist." You can spot the writer in a cameo, as Mr. Black, near the movie's end.
